content:
I presume this is an IMAP account, - click to account settings pane - click the synchronization&storage pane and then the 'advanced' button to verify that the desired folders can be downloaded - now, click File>offline>download from main menu - (if menu bar not showh, click the Alt key first) - this should dowload all messages - now, install the importexporttools NG addon - highlight each folder in the account, rightclick and select the importexport option to export messsages in whatever format you wish. - although not needed, I also suggest then highlighting Local Folders, rightclick and then use the importexport menu option to import from the exported media. That assures you that you have a good copy of the messages. - you can now close out the account.

And, just to clarify, Thunderbird does not have your data and never did; it's only an agent.
creator: davidsk

content: Oops, I forgot the second question. If this is a current version of thunderbird, click the account settings pane, and on right side of the account pane is a Delete button.
creator: davidsk

content:
If both users are using the same profile, then a transfer to new PC will handle for both. Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This will prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

To be sure your old pc is running a current version, click help>about to see version number
creator: davidsk

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
  9. Filtri eventualmente attivi
creator: @next

content: That is not a question that has a "because of this" answer. Because their spam filter thought the content was spam is about the closest anyone is going to be able to get to definitive answer as to why, Simply because we are not privy to how their spam filtering works makes anything further nothing more than a guess..

content:
- click to account settings pane - click the 'server settings' pane for her account - if POP, uncheck the boxes for checking and downloading mail - if IMAP, uncheck the boxes for checking for messages and the box to allow immediate server notification

IMAP cannot be guaranteed, as some IMAP servers will show incoming mail regardless

Sidenote: I have read snippers here and there that indicate the feature is being considered for a future release. But I'm not one who would know for sure.
creator: davidsk

content:
re :I wonder if my copy of Thunderbird has been compromised or the Thunderbird server has been compromised.

There is no such thing as 'Thunderbird server' for anyone using a free Thunderbird program. Emails are received into the server that handles your emails. That might be an email address provided by your Internet Service Provider or maybe a free email address such as those provided by gmail or it may be an email address you have because you have purchased a domain etc.

Thunderbird simply accesses the server and downloads whatever is in the server Inbox.

The server is set up to receive whatever is sent to it. You are paying that company to accept emails sent to your email address. Usually, servers have their own Spam filters to detect spam and then server usually puts those emails into the server Spam folder. You would only be able to see them if you created an Imap mail account. In webmail account, you can usually set up what is deemed as safe or unsafe sender, so server auto filters those into the Spam folder.

In Thunderbird, 'Account Settings' > 'Junk Settings' for each account - you can set up and train the Thunderbird Junk filter to recognise what you deem as Junk or Not Junk.


Why are you getting spam in the first place: Your email address is known by nefarious people and they are block sending spam mail to your email address. The Source View of your email should offer information on the initial source of sender maybe it includes an IP address. The top Received by will your server and the one closest to the From, Subject, To, Date headers will be the first server to receive the email.

Maybe your email address is displayed on some website so any search bot might discover it.

Advice on checking the date issue: You need to determine whether Thunderbird is involved in altering anything.

Process: I would suggest that you check the webmail account first thing in the morning before you start up Thunderbird. You would need to logon and check the webmail account to see if it displays all the same date/time for new spam mail. Make a note of the date/time or take a screendump image of server data. Then you will know whether the date time is all the same on server before it gets downloaded to Thunderbird. Once you have checked the server, start up Thunderbird, let it do the downloaded and notice if it displays same date/time as server when emails are downloaded.
creator: Toad-Hall
